citation.article-title: Pseudoruegeria lutimaris sp. nov., isolated from a tidal flat sediment, and emended description of the genus Pseudoruegeria
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudoruegeria lutimaris sp. nov.
Pseudoruegeria lutimaris (lu.ti.ma′ris. L. n. lutum mud; L. gen. n. maris of the sea, marine; N.L. gen. n. lutimaris of a marine mud).
Cells are non-motile, Gram-negative-staining rods, 0.4–0.6 μm in diameter and 1.0–8.0 μm long.
Colonies on MA are circular, convex, smooth, glistening, greyish yellow in colour and 1.0–1.5 mm after incubation for 5 days at 30 °C.
Anaerobic growth occurs on MA and on MA supplemented with nitrate.
Growth occurs at 10 and 37 °C, but not at 4 or 40 °C.
The optimal pH for growth is between pH 7.0 and 8.0; growth occurs at pH 5.0, but not at pH 4.5.
Optimal NaCl concentration for growth is approximately 2.0 % (w/v) NaCl.
Growth does not occur in the absence of NaCl or with >9.0 % (w/v) NaCl.
Na+ and Mg2+ ions are required for growth.
The major fatty acid is C18 : 1ω7c.
Fatty acids C16 : 0 and C12 : 0 3-OH are also detected.
The major polar lipids are phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, an unidentified aminolipid, an unidentified glycolipid and an unidentified lipid.
Other phenotypic characteristics are given in Table 1.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 73.5 mol% (HPLC).
The type strain, HD-43T (=KCTC 22690T =CCUG 57754T), was isolated from a tidal flat sediment from Hwang-do, an island of Korea.
